description:
Came here for drinks on a Friday evening with the boyfriend who lives in the Inner Richmond and frequents this bar fairly often. It was my first time and I loved it! I loved the bar environment, it was very inviting and social while still having a slightly-divey feel to it, which I really enjoy. There were no seats at the bar so we seated ourselves at one of the tall tables, of which there was plenty. We ordered a couple rounds of drinks - me with my usual G&Ts and my boyfriend got whiskey gingers. All our drinks were well-made, fairly strong (which we appreciated!) and reasonably priced. I think maybe $8 per drink which considering we were in SF is a pretty good deal to me. Also the bartender on Friday evening, who I believe is also the owner, is wonderful and very friendly, which makes the experience that much better. 

We did order some bar bites since we had skipped dinner, which were pretty basic and tasted like food from any other bar, but not bad by any means! I'm sure we'll be coming back here lots - it's my new favorite bar in the Inner Richmond for sure!
author: Abi R.

description:
Oh, how sad that the Bitter End was my bitter end of the bar crawl that my friends and I did after brunch one Sunday. This was our fourth and final stop, thank goodness. I was totally wasted but was still able to enjoy and observe what I love about this bar... the upstairs area. My friends and I grabbed our beers and headed upstairs where there were a few tables and no one else. Everyone was enjoying the game on the TVs downstairs.

This is a super divey and inexpensive location, which I appreciate. Not somewhere I'd opt to order cocktails unless it was a simple well drink. The beer selection is acceptable. There's even food! I probably should have ordered some of that. Definitely a hot spot to watch the game and hang out with your buddies. This isn't really my first-choice pub, but I'm glad I was able to check it out!
author: Stefanie C.

description:
The lady friend and I tried this spot after dinner. I remember going there during the late 90s/early 2000s and it's good to see that they are still around. It still had that cozy, slightly-divey feel to it, that I like so much. There were plenty of open tables and I was glad.  It was a Saturday night and I wasn't in the mood to be in a standing room only joint shouting in my friend's ear to converse.

The key elements of a good neighborhood bar: bartender who isn't stingy with alcohol, good music, a regular crowd (no hipsters/no gangstaz/no techies).  This is the kind of bar to drink, chew the fat and be merry.  I've been to hipster bars, gangster bars and techie bars.  They're fine, but I've always been more comfortable in dive bars.  Anyway, this bar fills the bill.  I had a pint of Stella and the lady had a cocktail.  I took sip of hers and the alcohol was nice.  We spent a couple of hours there, and I could've stayed there longer but didn't want to be out too late on the Thanksgiving weekend (maximum enforcement period for the Po-Po).  I saw a few patrol cars drive by and even stop right in front of the bar to have a converation with a rowdy bunch outside.

I don't go to bars nearly as much as I used to, but still love a places like this.  If you're looking for a pub that has a good selection of booze and just quiet (or not noisy) enough to carry on a converation.  This is a good chill spot if you're in the area
author: Rich H.

description:
I don't know if a $7 whiskey sour is acceptable for the size of the glass, but I don't care because this bar is so inviting. It's casual and chill, and has such hipster decor (like the lights in my pictures.) The upstairs consists of the women's bathroom, along with a pool table and some dart boards. It's overlooking the bar downstairs so you could people-watch if you get bored. lol It's a perfect location to have a good Friday night out with your friends. 

The music was an absolute plus--they were playing The Police all night!!! I had a great time.
author: Nishi S.

description: Great place to grab a drink. Friendly bartenders and the drinks are reasonably priced.
author: Edwin N.

description:
When I was younger, I was convinced the only bars worth drinking at were trendy, modern, and expensive. Now that I am a bit older and wiser, I really prefer places like The Bitter End - well worn, well loved, and possibly a git grungy. 

On a Saturday afternoon, there was no problem grabbing a seat at the bar or a nearby table, although service was slow with just one person behind the bar. This is an eclectic little neighborhood bar with a good selection of whatever-your-poison-may-be, and pub food.

My only gripe was I paid $7 for a gin and tonic that was more tonic than gin. Later I ordered a shot of gin for $7, which definitely came with 100% more gin than was in my drink. At least while we were there, this was not a dive bar that serves stiff drinks.
author: Claire S.

description:
$17 for a glass of wine and an Irish coffee? No thanks
Patrons around me were surprised and shocked so we questioned the lady bartender. She stuck by the price.
Never again 
Too many better options in this area
author: Lauraine E.

description:
The Bitter End is a neat little neighborhood bar.  What I like about it is that it is casual, affordable but well stocked.  The folks there are friendly, and the food decent.  TV screens will show you whatever sports game is on, on any given day - although I would not call it a sports bar.

The Side Bar across the street is a cozier place - see my review - but it does not serve food.  The Bitter End has a lot of competition, on Clement St. between Arguello and 6th avenue there are a lot of little bars and pubs, but it holds its own, and it should be frequented.

I'd recommend it for a casual drink, some solid unpretentious food, and if you are with a group it will probably suit you better than smaller places like the Side Bar.
author: Massimo M.

description:
The Bitter End is one of those perfectly acceptable Bar and Restaurants that gets the job done.  I don't have anything negative to say about The Bitter End.  At the same time, if someone asked me where to go grab food in the Inner Richmond, I wouldn't recommend that they make it a priority to visit.  

Personally, I'm a fan of any place where you can sit at the bar, grab a beer or a cocktail, watch some TV and order some food.  This is your place.  You can come for either Pub Food or for Brunch.  They have a solid selection of tap beer.  It's not quite an all on Sports Bar, but you can get a good look at TV's if that's your plan.  I've done the Burger here a couple of times and it's unexceptional, but not too pricey.  Likewise, I'd say the same of the Brunch.  I'm not saying anything overtly negative, but it didn't give me reason to be proactively positive.  I would definitely give the nod to nearby Richmond Republic Draught House in terms of food.  (Hearsay Food Review - I know someone who really seems to like the Sheppard's Pie)

Bar-wise, it's got some good things working in it's favor.  Full bar.  Laid back clientele.  Cool activities area upstairs with a couple of pool tables and darts.  The service seems friendly enough.  I've never found it to be overly crowded or loud.  The prices aren't too bad, either.  In short, you can certainly do a lot worse.  

I wouldn't go out of my way, but this is an easy spot to grab a low key meal and a drink out on Clement Street.  If I lived pretty close, this would be a regular staple since it's not super-expensive and has never disappointed.
author: Adam S.

description:
We stopped by here on a slow week night, and we're very disappointed.
It's so dark that we could see the menu?!? We had to use a flash light.
The water had such a bad taste, that it was undrinkable.  Since no one ever came back to our table to check on us, I went to back and asked for a different water, it was just as bad, some sort of disinfectant residue.  I ordered the pork chops, they were by far the thinnest cuts I have ever seen, and burnt.  My wife ordered steak, she could only choke down a couple bites and left the rest.  Her mashed potatoes were so over salted, that neither one of us could eat it. 
The only good thing was the sampler plate of appetizers, it was tasty.  

Pro's: 
nothing

Con's:
Poor quality food
Price
Parking
Slow service
author: C J.

description:
Used to be a nice spot but the bar staff was very incompetent in my last visit.

We waited at the bar for almost 10 minutes and was not served.

Had to leave after wasting my time.
author: Can I.

description: We missed happy hour draft beer. Fried prawns was excellent. I will go back once a week to this place.
author: Is A.

description: Been there a couple times before. Seemed decent enough. Went in on a Saturday night, grabbed seats at the bar with my wife. The place started getting crowded, but we were patient as we waited to order our second round for 5, then 10, then 20, then 25 minutes while I made eye contact with the bartenders, expressed our wish to order. Eventually got very fed up, demanded my check, and left forever. Amateur hour plus college bros.
author: Ben A.

description: My favorite bar in the Richmond. The music can be a little loud sometimes, but if you're looking for a friendly place in the neighborhood to just relax and have a drink or two, this is the place. The patrons and bartenders are all very welcoming.
author: Connor C.

description:
I cannot stress enough how much this bar ended up being the "San Francisco" bar for me and my friends. Awesome drinks, pool table, cheap prices, and actually pretty delicious food. (Try their Salmon dinner).

It's the pinnacle go-to place while all the other SF bars keep upping their prices, installing more "modern" wood panels, and attracting the same tech bros.

The Bitter End is a no frills, no bullshit, wonderful pub.
author: Carlos C.

description: Absolutely loved this place when I lived in the Inner Richmond. It's a mix of Irish pub and classic dive bar. The drinks were always cheap, normal pub grub, bar games and sports on the TV. It's a great place to catch the San Francisco Giants play and have a beer with friends. It's also a great place to play some billiards or darts, both of which are on the second floor. Lastly, they had an awesome Trivia night on Tuesdays, but make sure you get there early because it fills up quickly. Last but not least, the same bar tenders were always there and always a delight. Good people all around.
author: Tevis S.

description:
I am a big fan of Hash Browns and the hash Browns here is one of my favor. They made it just right, not too raw or over cooked. Their Garlic Cheese Fries was pretty good too. I guess they must have hired some good chefs. 

In addition to good food, they have friendly staff too. Everyone was so nice and entertaining.

Giving it 5 stars. You deserve it!
author: Ricardo H.

description: The Bitter End is a neighborhood fixture that has been around for a long time. Lots of USF students drink here. The crowd is friendly and usually pretty talkative. It fills up quickly on weekends. They tend to play good music, an eclectic mix of old and new songs. Drinks are strong and reasonably priced. Definitely a local favorite watering hole.
author: Jeromy C.

description:
Came here for trivia one Tuesday night and had a lot of fun! Great spot, lots of people participating. 

Gotta admit, the service was a little slow. Right when I got there my friends who had been sitting there for awhile said we were supposed to wait for the server to take our order at the table - waited about 15 min before a server came up to us and asked what we wanted to drink. Totally understand it's busy there for trivia - not a huge deal. 

It was also pretty hard to hear the trivia announcer (emcee?). it could have been the location of our table, since it was right next to him, who knows?

Still had a great time and would come back!
author: Ilana B.

description:
The Bitter End...Thanks for always giving me a good end of a night. This is a great cheap dive bar, but the music is always loud and the crowd can get kind of rowdy. 

Downstairs is a bar with lots of beer on tap (New Castle, Guinness, Anchor Steam) and cider on tap. A pint of cider or beer is $4-5 while a pitcher is $18. The bar tenders are super friendly and try to be super fast - I suggest ordering from the right side of the bar to get noticed. 

There's open seating everywhere and the upstairs has a few pool tables and darts. I just love the overall feel and diveyness of the place. It is loud, but it is a great chill kind of night - nothing too aggressive. This is a great night cap or pre game kind of place!
author: Eric Joseph D.

description:
I love this place. Good, cheap food. Reasonable draft beer selection. Martina and Pascal are incredible bartenders - always kind and calm, even when the place is slammed, and seem genuinely happy to see familiar faces. 

Trivia Tuesdays with Timmy get pretty packed, but if you arrive around 30 minutes early, you should get a seat and you'll have a blast. 

My only complaint is that sometimes there's another bartender working - really tall dude with curly hair - and he always, always, ALWAYS messes up drink orders. Order a whiskey ginger? You'll get a whiskey soda. Order a Racer 5? You'll get a Heroin. Order a water with no ice? You'll get a glass of ice. 

Regardless of his blunders, worth a visit. Martina and Pascal more than make up for any of this other dude's errors. Should they ever leave their post, I'd be crushed.
author: Tiffany S.

description:
Pitchers of beer, darts & pool!!!

Great place to hang out with your friends. Not one those ratchet bar, it's relatively quiet, perfect for nights where you just want to catch up with your friends and still be able to hear every word they are saying without having to scream at each other!
author: Kelly L.

description:
Ah, The Bitter End.

When I first walked in, I didn't expect it to be so loud.  The music made it somewhat difficult to get a smooth conversation going without having to yell WHAT? HUH?  He finally came and we walked around the bar and upstairs to find a quieter spot.

The night started off fine with the typical generic topics of life and ish.  Then somehow one joke after another, I somehow managed to destroy this guy's presence here by questioning his existence on earth.  By the end of the night, I compared him to the Zika Virus in that he is hated by many, he destroys people's lives, and some smart scientist is on the path of finding a vaccine to get rid of him.  His response, "At least I was remembered for something big".  Hah, what a good sport.

Got the Stella which was only $4!  What a steal.  Also got the basket of fries which was about $6.50?  It got busy around 9ish.  Service was great.
author: Linda N.

description:
I came to The Bitter End with a large group after an afternoon at the 540 Club and a reading at Green Apple, making this the last of three stops on a long, wonderful day in the Inner Richmond. I was a little drunk when I arrived, and I was at least as drunk when I left, without any disasters either in between or after. But I guess "The Safe, Pleasant End" doesn't have much of a ring to it.

We were able to walk in without difficulty with like eight to ten people on a Monday night between 8 and 9. We got a nice row of tables downstairs and pretty much had the whole place to ourselves. This is a great thing for a neighborhood bar. The bartender was nice, if I remember correctly, and I think I had one or two Racer 5 IPAs. The beer selection was decent, though I thought 540 Club's was better.

I also ate dinner here, choosing, for whatever reason, the grilled salmon with salsa. My friends gave me shit about ordering salmon at a pub when there were so many pubby items on the menu, but I must've been in the mood for some healthy-ass grilled fish? I don't know. I enjoyed it in any case. Not the kind of entree you'd come to The Bitter End to consume, but a moderate $12.50 and was perfectly serviceable. It came with some kind of a vegetable medley and a choice of garlic mashed potatoes or french fries. Those details are lost to time.

I had a lot of fun at The Bitter End and would spend some time here if I lived in the area. It's a cool bar with a calm vibe and some food for when you need it. Seems like it has all it needs to be a neighborhood stalwart.
author: Steph C.

description: The Bitter End is a San Francisco institution. They always have old school jams playing on the juke box and local sports on TV (go Giants!). I've ended up here on many weekends out and always have a blast here with my friends. I have to mention the weekend bartender, Isaac, the tall handsome guy with curly hair. Isaac is a San Francisco native and the best damn bar tender in the whole city. He is super charming and funny, and if you ask right, maybe, just maybe, there might be a secret drink menu with all sorts of special drinks. Five stars!
author: Coleman M.

description: My second visit to The Bitter End and once again - Linda was friendly and professional, and made me feel completely welcome and comfortable.  It's a super laid back and comfortable on a Saturday afternoon.  The curry fries are delicious - and the kitchen even made me a special order of beer battered onions to go with the mushrooms (delicious, thanks Yolanda!).
author: Jenn C.

description: i was not impressed by this place. at all. came here for a drink on st. patty's day before eating at wako and the bartender was super rude, gave us terrible pours of beer with ALL of the foam, and then didnt acknowledge his mistake. gross.
author: Christina L.

description: Good ambiance, plenty of space, love the pear cider on tap!
author: Monica L.

description: Ok bar. Nothing special. Ordered a Jameson and coke, which is hard to mess up so can't complain on that one. Bartender wasn't the nicest and wasn't very attentive. He was more concerned about continuing his side conversation sitting at the bar.
author: Antonella H.

description: 5:00pm, bar nearly empty. I order a burger, it takes 29 minutes to arrive? I was about to get up and leave. Not going back, thank you.
author: Bruno R.

description: What a lovely bar! And most importantly, what lovely bartenders! Nothings makes me happier than friendly bartender women!!! Kudos! We stopped here for some finger food and drinks during happy hour while waiting for our table at Burma - so close and convenient if you have to wait for table at your restaurant. Nice house wine, lovely IPAs and finger food - don't have too much of the batter fried stuff cause it's quite heavy :P. Had a great time, will be back again for sure!
author: Heliana M.

description:
Solid bar on Friday nights, was kind of pack but not hard to order some drinks. It's got a fun atmosphere and neat set up with a pool table/darts upstairs. A beer was $5 compared to $6 at  most bars in the city. There's a $10 minimum for credit card users, which might make you open a tab, but the drinks are worth it. On Wednesday it's kind of relaxed and not as crowded compared to Friday nights. The social scene wasn't bad either mainly people in their twenties. 
Looking forward to coming back sometime.
author: Dan G.

description:
I come here for trivia every Tuesday. Love this place. Great dive bar atmosphere with an Irish couple running the bar and grill. 

Good people come here.
author: Ryan L.

description:
Cheap and good drinks. Great place to hang out before you head out for the night.

The service is super fast like it should be in a dive!!
author: Ujwal C.

description:
Surprisingly interesting bar in the Richmond area

Before walking in, the place looked pretty small from the outside--I didn't expect anything other than a typical neighborhood bar. Turns out, when you walk in, it's a large 2-story establishment, with lots of customers, energetic background music, and bartenders who look like they have been working there for years and knows a lot of the local customers. The service is professional, and there are pool tables and darts on the 2nd floor. The customers are usually large groups of family or coworkers who go there to chat and hang out.

Definitely one of the more interesting bars I've seen in SF, with a nice group vibe. Would recommend stopping by.
author: Henry L.

description:
I see why The Bitter End has become my sister's favorite watering hole. The atmosphere is laid back, casual, and a great place to chill with friends over a beer or two.

At first glance, it doesn't look like much, but once you step inside, you'll see a restaurant area and then the bar area in the back. There's also a second story for those packed Friday and Saturday nights. The bartenders are all experienced and know how to have a good time. Don't be shy to pull up a stool and chat with them; they are half of the experience.

The other half, of course, is the booze. There is a great selection of beers on tap, and they usually have more than one cider on tap. If you're feeling more adventurous, tell the bartenders to surprise you with a drink, and they'll give you one of their concoctions (that are usually pretty tasty).

If you've got the munchies, don't hesitate to order some fries or other food to snack on if the kitchen is still open. I hear their shepherd's pie is to die for!
author: Yvonne K.

description:
If you've lived in SF long enough, hopefully you know this is THE place for trivia within the city's limits. It's like the Michigan Stadium of Irish bars as they seem to pack 100,000 enthusiasts in there every Tuesday night without overwhelming you. It's quite remarkable.

As for the bar itself - it's your standard pub grub fare with everything you'd expect from a local's bar and the drinks are sufficiently inexpensive. If you're lucky enough to score a parking spot just outside the bar on Clement - even better. 

If you fancy yourself a trivia buff, you really need to make this a regular stop.
author: Ruggy J.

description: A standard pub which, honestly, can be exactly what a person's looking for. Beers and ciders on tap are great. Liquor selection good. Bartenders, nice enough. Big screens. Little fire blazing and you might be lucky enough to sit near the hearth. Food... you gotta like deep fried (very likely frozen) food. Calamari rings were 2" to 3" across, no tentacles. Suspicious. But if you don't have a strong stomach, you can end up with heartburn. It wasn't too crowded, I had a good time with my friends, so if you've been hanging out at Green Apple, it's a swell neighborhood joint but not worth a trek.
author: Nini M.

description:
This place is wonderful! Just a terrific place to hang and drink great beverages while feeling you are tucked away in the English countryside.

Try the chicken breast burger. Unexpectedly delicious.  They put avocado and bacon and cheese on it. I always get this.

The bartenders here are are awesome. They work so hard. It's usually just them running around and tending bar and shuttling food from the kitchen. They handle it well.
author: Lucy P.

description:
Decent dive-bar. Go on a weekday night and you'll see a lot of SF technies loitering around trying to be cool in their foot-long bacteria engrossed beards and shoes that cost more than my entire wardrobe. Go on a weekend night and you'll see the same thing but this time with women who are trying to act non-chalant about the Brawny man trying to take her home.

Drinks are moderately priced and they have a good selection of stuff on hand, including good whiskey. The bartender (male) tends to be drunk... so make your drinks basic. Upstairs has a dart area that's engulfed in darkness and the other side is a pool table or two with a non-working pay phone (we tried) and lots of people hanging over each other in drunken stupor. While people watching (holy shoes this place is good for that) we witnessed 2 or 3 maybe-hook up's happen and one gal take a bro home. Good on you, gal!

I don't mind it overall, and when in SF and needing a dive bar that isn't clustered with imbeciles (check out the places across the street) and in a safer 'hood, this place is our go-to. It's also not far from Sutro Baths which is great for late-night hooking up. 

There's also a really cool suit of armor upstairs that you can't touch :(
author: Alexandria C.

description: YES, my favorite dive bar in SF. Darts, pool, Tuesday night Trivia - what more can you ask for. From the outside, it looks like your standard small Irish pub but it's surprisingly spacious with two floors. This is a great place to come unwind and relax - you will not be disappointed.
author: Karen C.

description:
I normally do not go to the bitter end: Within staggering distance there are many other "Irish" drinking establishments....that I prefer. 

You know the place is a bit dumpy when you are hanging with a friend and a drunk Irishmen turns around and asks her: are ya Irish....would you like a wee bit more Irish in ya.

Nice way to go...never heard that one before. They pour a good Guinness. The food is passable...but pretty greasy and inconsistent.

Location is not my fav: This block of Clement is nasty dirty. The bar itself is not so clean as well.

I do like the pool tables. Early in the evening you actually can carry on a conversation...especially upstairs.
author: David G.

description: Bitter End is such a nice bar to hang out at, you feel like you are in England or Ireland.  They have a great selection of beer on tap.  I love Clement Street for all the great Asian restaurants, so I make a point to stop at Bitter End for a beer.  Friendly Bartenders, just a nice SF spot.  Great neighborhood.
author: Carole W.

description: While the exterior may be hard to miss, it has a nice old-school feel to it.  When you walk in, it's like you're walking to a time in the Richmond district from generations ago.  This place serves food, but I haven't had it before.  The drinks are your standard drinks like Sierra Nevada and Stella Artois, but you really come for the atmosphere.  It could get a little crowded, and room to walk can get a little tight.  It's also not great that they just have one bartender manning the bar when a GSW playoff game is on, but they're still cool people who will get to you when they can.  The patrons are diverse where you have the barflies, the bros, and the locals.  It's enjoyable though to see such a melting pot of people who want to drink, watch sports, and have a good time.
author: Chan L.

description:
The Guinness is good! 

That is all you need to know.... Oh and it's a great place to wait (ages), for your table at Burma Superstar.
author: Jaylena P.

description:
For a couple of years now, my group has defaulted to Mad Dog in the Fog for trivia nights. It was always crowded but never felt like a truly engaged community. The Bitter End reminded me of my favorite local Irish pub back in Seattle and I immediately fell into its shabby-chic embrace. 

From the outside, it looks like your standard issue Irish pub but it's surprisingly spacious with two floors of seating. There's ample booth space so showing up at 8 pm for a 9 pm trivia (Tuesday evenings), I had my Goldilocks' choice of places to sit. The waitresses have friendly Irish lilts and flit about at just the right time to re-fill pitchers and clear away plates. The food is nothing to sneeze at (think curry fries that tasted a bit like gravy, Shepherd's Pie, etc) but the beers on tap are a plenty!

Now for the trivia format: never underestimate how much time is saved by having another team grade your answers. We're all grown-ups here; (most) of us wouldn't cheat. The team name with the most crowd-whooping reaction (usually as un-PC as possible) gets a round of shots on the house with the top three places receiving cash monies ranging from $10 to $30. There was a healthy mix of topics covered from presidents to history to music and pop culture. Bonus: a live musician decided to pump up the trivia goers with some sing-alongs, just for kicks and giggles. Camaraderie? It's here in spades!
author: Faith Y.

description: I love this place. The food is available, the drinks plentiful, and the people watching enjoyable. I love it when the bartenders kick out under-agers on Friday nights. You gotta wait your turn just like the rest of us honey! The only thing I would change about this place is the frequency that the fireplace is lit. It should be on every night in my opinion and it isn't.
author: Kayli B.

description: It's a great local dive bar. It doesn't get too crowded as well! It's a laid back atmosphere and pretty casual. They have great selection of beers and well drinks. They have typical bar food: burger, chicken wings, chicken strips, fries, steak, ect. I'd recommond coming here!
author: Jenn L.

description:
Really?! I haven't reviewed this place before? Strange, since this was one of my go-to spots when I first moved to SF.

I've been to trivia night a few times back in the day and always had a good time even though I think the games are rigged. Can someone really know that much baseball trivia? 

Anyway, the service can be up or down but overall it's a good time here.

Even though I'm not the biggest fan of Irish pubs, this one is A-O-K!
author: Art O.

description:
the first time i came here (years ago) it was to cure a hangover, and it worked perfectly.

the second time (more recently), Bernie and Hillary were bickering on TV like an old married couple. we went upstairs and sipped our beers in peace.

the third time, the Warriors were dominating, so we went upstairs and sipped our fernets in peace.

bottom line: they have TVs, but they also have tons of space, a sweet loft with a pool table, and it's never overwhelming.
author: Ronny K.

description: I was harassed by a regular multiple times and the woman-bartender said, 'it's a bar, what do you expect?!?!'!!  I am a woman, hanging out with a friend and not bothering anyone else, but this behavior isn't ok. So I said something about it, but apparently the regular was more important and I got TRUMPED!!!!! I will never go back here again.
author: A P.

description: Love the environment here! Cheap drinks and a cute dog named Swisher to greet you at the door. Great selection of beers. Favorite part was the upstairs pool area. If you're looking for a dive bar in the Richmond, go here!
author: Carmelisa M.

description:
Tonight I walked in the door and headed to the bathroom, and on my way back to the bar the bar tender comes running at me and demands my ID. He then asks me what my birthday is and what my address is to verify that it's my ID. Then he starts to hand it back and bends the hell out of it and says that it feels flimsy, implying that he doesn't believe it's real. Maybe because I still have the old style of California ID and perhaps it's thinner than the new ones, but if you're going to hardcore accuse someone of having a fake ID, at least know what all current state IDs look and feel like that are in circulation. I can't be the only person without the newest version of the California ID. 

My point isn't to make a complaint about being carded, though. I really don't mind being carded because I know it's the bar's responsibility to keep underage people out so I'm not disappointed with that. But the bar tender's accusatory tone/attitude and the fact that he seemed SO determined to prove that my ID was fake were completely unnecessary and really rude. It's really possible to be firm, but still respectful, but this bar tender definitely wasn't the latter. Did not seem like a welcoming environment for some 25 year old friends stopping in for a drink on a Wednesday...

The friends I was with and I won't be bringing our business back here anytime soon if we're not going to be treated with respect.
author: Robert M.

description:
Went here on a Saturday night with a friend and it was alright. I feel like if this bar was a man it would be some big burley man who liked shooting things, wearing flannel and is one of those people who salutes the American flag every time they walk past it. 

Being a 22 year old woman who enjoys places who don't smell like old wooden boxes, this wasn't exactly my cup of tea. 

It was a nice place to sit and chat, and they have a great selection of beer, but, this definitely isn't my scene. So if you're one of those truly troubled individuals who finds it acceptable to wear blue jeans and a north face jacket to bars, then have at it. Because this is your watering hole. Cheers.
author: Molly S.

description: Pretty great dive-bar! Went on a Saturday night and found it not too crowded, which was great. They had a good selection of beers on tap, ample seating, two pool tables, and two dart boards. The place looks smaller from outside, but then you realize there's a whole other floor to it. It's a pretty cozy place and the vibe is super chill. Definitely coming back here.
author: Kristine N.

description: Great place to stop for beers and pool if you're in the inner richmond.  We came here after a game in the presidio and I can't vouch for the food or the waitstaff but our beers were never empty and we had the entire second floor basically to ourselves to hang out and play pool.  It was a great place for a large group and I would definitely return if in the neighborhood and craving a nice cold beer.  Oh, and also to creepily people watch from the second floor, but that's just me..
author: Raina D.

description: Been waiting here for 20 mins and not even been asked for a drink. She is probably the worst bartender I have seen, she is lost or drunk hard to figure out.
author: Nik P.

description: Wow. This place is an institution, and this is my favorite bar in SF. Why? Because of the staff. Everyone here *rules*. They are so kind, personable, helpful, funny, and *real*. No nonsense- amazing service, a friendly vibe, and good times every time. Never once had a even a neutral experience here, I always have a good time! Thank you, Bitter End!!!! :)
author: Katie R.

description:
An irish pub with more than one cider on tap...YES PLEASE! There is a jukebox full of good music and the vibe is low-key.  There are darts to play upstairs and plenty of group tables and spots at the bar to enjoy a drink.

This a is a great place to blow off steam after work, they have a decent happy-hour menu full of snacks that are easily shared and they know how to pull a proper pint of Guinness.
author: Amy L.

description: Great local dive bar! Met up with a few friends here for the first time, the other day. I was pretty surprised that the place wasn't too crowded, considering the day and the late night hour. Pretty casual and laid back atmosphere make this place a great place to meet up and hang out. Good selection of beers, too. I wish I had more hands so that I could give this place 4 thumbs up! I will definitely be returning to The Biter End.
author: Andrew M.

description: Great little neighborhood bar that usually isn't too crowded. The bartender is really nice and relaxed. This place is a great little gem to go and have a quiet, pleasant night out for some drinks with friends.
author: Dylan M.

description:
Mixed up.

Previous night had been Blown Away by Markus Schulz' first night at Ruby Skye: http://open.spotify.com/track/3Z7LUEtBWGt8zNXH7LuZCo

Was so famished everything about the Bitter End Mixed Grill (Irish bacon, sausage, two eggs, grilled tomato, baked beans, hash browns and toast) sounded good.

Except the pork. Figured it wouldn't hurt to see if they'd swap it for teriyaki-glazed chicken. Blown away again that they were willing to do it.

Devoured the meal with as much enthusiasm as Markus had devoured us. Chicken was so good. Snuck a few juicy bites of the bacon and sausage. Baked beans brilliant.

All for an extremely reasonable $13 plus tax and well deserved tip. Left ready and Reloaded for Markus night two: http://open.spotify.com/track/1WS5vViJ1AO1RWSXYztVe9
author: Jason B.

description: I've found myself here many times in the past few years with larger groups. They have a big area for seating, but the wait at the bar can get kind of long. Pool tables upstairs. Real divey, locals, place, decent bar food. $4 drafts during happy hour, 4-6pm.
author: Jess B.

description:
It's the best bar in America, by virtue of subtraction. Let me explain.

1. It's not a performance space. There's no room for it, so unless you're running the music round at Tuesday Trivia (at 9pm), take your guitar elsewhere.

2. It's not a dance hall. Again, there's no room for it. While there's a jukebox, it isn't meant to be your DJ. The disco ball is only utilized once a year.

3. It isn't known to be a great restaurant, though the food is pretty decent. Nothing to write home about, but if you need a bite (until 10pm), their fare will more than suffice.

4. It's not a sports bar. There are three tv sets whose content is skewed towards bay area teams. If you want to catch your favorite out-of-market team this isn't the place to do it.

5. It's not a place to "be seen." Sure, you might run into some attractive patrons, but nobody gets dolled up to go to the Bitter. You'll find people from the neighborhood and a lot of locals, dressed, well, normally. Miniskirts and stripey shirts are rare, though feel free.

Think about why you go to a bar in the first place, then cut the crap. What are you left with? 

A comfortable place to talk, and booze.

The Bitter provides both of these well, and nothing else.
author: Charles C.

description: What can I say this is my go-to neighborhood bar and I love it with all my heart.
author: Nick R.

description:
I love bars that serve food, good bar food that is. Go ahead, just pick something on the menu and order it.

Plenty of seating areas downstairs plus the men's bathroom.

Upstairs consist of the women's bathroom, pool table, and darts. Plenty of seating up here as well.

Good place to watch the games!
author: Nancy N.

description:
I've only been here once with a friend, and while it didn't blow my socks off, we stayed until close and had a good time.  We like to play pool, and after about an hour and a half, a table opened up.  There are two pool tables upstairs, along with two dart... things (I don't play darts, there's two bullseye mofos on the wall) on the opposite side up stairs.  This is also where the bathrooms are.  Nothing is more terrifying than watching drunk people throw sharp, pointy things in your general direction when you're waiting in line to pee.

The pitchers were a pretty good deal, the place was packed, and overall we had a good time.  They serve food there, but a part of me died inside when I went "I'M STARVING" at 11pm and found out they stop serving at 10pm.  I wish they'd serve food a little later so I'm not forced to go to Jack-in-the-Box for things that will make me hate myself later.

The bartender was great, and fast, and friendly.  There's an ATM inside the bar to cover all of your cash needs.  Parking is a complete whore, given that it's located in Inner Richmond.

I wish we'd have made it out for a Tuesday Trivia night, based on some of the reviews for this place.  This place is great for groups, overall, and something tells me a group would be great for Trivia night.
author: Hope O.

description: Keep your expectations low and that is what I did.  I had a great time at Bitter End. Drinks are cheap and it doesn't get too loud so you can actually talk to your friends without having to scream. A good neighborhood bar, with a two floor setup. Good for games, groups, locals...has some pool tables and dart boards and sports on the TVs.  Nice place to hang with friends!
author: Maria M.

description:
Decided to venture out of my regular watering hole and stepped into The Bitter End. I was pleasantly surprised! There is plenty of seating and the bartenders are attentive and friendly for the most part. I'm interested in seeing how their Trivia Night goes on Tuesdays.

This is definitely on my list of go-to places. It does tend to get rowdy on Friday and Saturday nights, but if you're looking for a quiet night during that time of the week, then a bar probably isn't your best choice.

They should just start an IV for me with that Raspberry cider. I can drink it all day!
author: Sara K.

description:
A fun Irish themed bar in San Francisco - or Inner Richmond, whatever I'm from San Diego and I was here on a quick trip for the weekend!

Not much to say, we went here on a Saturday night fairly early so it wasn't very busy and there wasn't any games going on. We had good service and were served drinks quickly and at a good price. There's pool tables upstairs and darts so that's always good. I would def. go back here if I'm up the area again!
author: Travis S.

description: The male bartender with brown hair was a crybaby. He told me that me and my friends were 'shitty tippers' after I payed him exact change for a drink and BEFORE he bothered to serve me. Wtf do your job and I'll tip you accordingly.
author: Brady L.

description:
Getting an "Irish Breakfast" on a Sunday after battling a cold helped a lot. Getting a cider beer during the week on tap is worth it. Pricing is reasonable considering it's a bar. 
(The only person to treat me out to this place dumped me 2 days later on my b-day after our Irish Breakfast. He's such an asshole for doing that!)
author: Anni Y.

description:
This is a review of the Tuesday night pub quiz. Best local pub quiz I've been to all year. 

The bartenders and guys running it were hilarious. And the regulars sitting to our left and right made us all feel right at home. 

We're coming back next week, no question about it.
author: Mike V.

description: Went to the Bitter End when we found ourselves in the Inner Richmond with empty tummies. The fried mushrooms are delectable, I would go again just for them. Great selection of various ciders as well. Yum!
author: Jennifer P.

description:
Trivia night and the bartender are the reason I go to this place. When I still ate meat I was also obsessed with their pepper steak. It is an Irish pub with a fun, friendly and welcoming atmosphere. Great place for friends to hang out, feel embarrassed that they forgot who William McKinley was and share shots with a pun-filled bartender. 

They also have pool and darts upstairs but I suck at those things. The ALSO really need a new P.A..
author: Andrew K.

description: Spent my early college years parading around the Inner Richmond bars.  So much parading, that I rarely walk into a bars now.   However, headed back to the Bitter End one rainy afternoon with my bro and remembered why I liked this place.  I love the booths! The little red candles.  The Irish ex pats at the bar, pool tables upstairs, full length mirror near the bathroom, and the very awesome McLaren Scotch.  Have never tried the food, but love the option.  Nothing like strollin up and down clement after a few drinks.
author: Chelsey G.

description:
Good food...I had the Shepherds Pie!  It wag great!  Not sure, but I think I could have shared this.  The service was good and friendly.  Nice crowd and a good spot to enjoy watching a game.

I truly enjoyed this place and will be back!
author: Kenneth G.

description:
The Bitter End: This bar is cavernous in the most magical sense. It's huge! Two floors of funkiness. Located in the inner Richmond, at 5th & Clement, this bar is truly a leader in its class--of dive bars that is.

To start with the most important factor of any bar, dive or otherwise; the drinks! Here, the drinks are fast, cheap, good and the well liquors are premium. They serve food beginning at 5p.m. and the menu ranges from pub grub and beyond. I ate the curry chicken fries, and have been jonesing for them ever since.  Freshly prepared French fries, smothered in gravy like curry sauce and small bits of chicken laced throughout. On the other end of the spectrum, my boyfriend had salmon and steamed veggies.

The décor is the best of what dive bars represents; a medieval knight hanging from the ceiling, dust bunnies trailing from his mask, deer heads with Medusa like snakes coming out, televisions, pool tables, a juke box and walls buried under kitschy memorabilia and a collection of taxidermied things.This bar is well worth the journey. For more fun, photos and information, check out my blog at: http://thenoisebeneaththeapple.com/
author: Heather J.

description:
This place is awesome.  Came here on a Monday night and enjoyed the $3.00 happy hour.  I drank several raspberry ciders - which I thought were tasty, but friends later thought tasted like watered down Robitussin.  They also have pear and apple cider on tap.  

Efficient service, cold drinks and bar food in case you get hungry.  What's not to like?
author: Kathleen W.

description:
Love this place...2 ciders on tap. 
Great happy hour 4-7pm M-F!!
They have pool tables and darts. 
Totally has a very oldtimey feel like I just got finished mining gold and sold my flakes so I could come blow my money on booze
Sorry....I got lost in a imaginary nostalgic, contemporary adapted dreamscape....
But cool place!! 
I recommend you come and spend your hard earned gold flakes...but don't worry prices are so fair you will have much left over to pay for your nice warm monthly bath
author: Doug G.

description:
Sometimes I can not for the life of me decide which of the 10 gazillion Clement Street restaurants I should eat at.  When this happens, it's nice to have a pub nearby.  Forget about trying to figure out what genre of food you want.  Just go to the Bitter End and get some great pub grub!!

I recently enjoyed an amazing teriyaki pork chop here.  Washed it down with a cold pint of Harp.  The amazing thing about this place is that the food is delicious, but it seems to appear out of no where.  I am still trying to figure out where the kitchen is.   If someone can tell me, please do!

Seriously though, I've never had a bad eating or drinking experience at the Bitter End.  Friendly staff, a nice selection of beer, and reasonable prices.  The Tuesday night Trivia is a nice touch too!
author: Tim N.

description:
Who MANDATES that the trivia night include the question, "Jew or not a Jew"

Are we not living in 2014?

I will never be back.  How can I support a business who encourages the same behavior that started the Holocaust?

Also, when I asked the owner/bar tender how he could allow/mandate/encourage this, he said, "well we've been doing it for ten years," as if that is somehow a reason.  Just because you are doing something for ten years, does not make it right - I explained.

His next response was, "well my Jewish friend isn't offended."  Well guess what, just because one person isn't offended, doesn't mean that nobody is!

So he calls his friend over, who tells me he's jewish and not offended....we have a debate and in the process he explains he's an atheist....

um, what? 

yea.... this is the logic?

no, thank you
author: R P.

description:
Judging from the name, I always decided not to go here cause I assumed it was ****hole. (Don't ask me why I even did).

Bad judgement! 

A great, casual/divey hang out spot with decent pub-food and a pool upstairs.
Everyone is super friendly and this is a cool spot to watch games at.

One downside is, there's only 1 bathroom and it's upstairs!
author: Helen D.

description: Great dive bar. Homey feeling. Ok beer selection and good food menu. Plenty of seating.
author: Jenn A.

description:
First off, great name!
A bar with two stories is just a bar that wants trouble, especially when one of those floors is unsupervised. I 'm not going to divulge the the stuff I saw upstairs at The Bitter End but it weren't quite polite.
The downstairs was more of a normal person's area so I was torn and felt like I was on the stairs all night!.
The food's okay, the drinks is fine, the time was weird. Don't play darts with people who hate you.
author: Alexander R.

description:
Great local spot for the inner Richmond / Clement locals. Fun trivia too. 

This bar is fairly low - key, but it can still get pretty packed Thursday/Friday. The high tables in the front are the best for bringing your friends for conversation, upstairs is the pool table but it's always.. always taken.

Cash Only!
author: Cruz K.

description:
I need to come back for Trivia Night, that's for sure.

This was the last stop of the night for us on a recent bar-hopping night out. The bouncer, who knows the BF by name is SUPER nice and tolerant of our annoying drunkeness. The bartender was also very nice, giving our drunken friend a glass of water after last call.

I'll be returning for trivia night and for those bottles of Fernet on the wall.
author: Veronica C.

description:
holy smokes, batman! didn't even know about this place down the street from me. Yes, i've only been there once, but it was ama-wait for it-zingly great. cheap pitchers of sweet sweet cider (and beer), and pool tables for a buck. Granted, ours was missing a ball, but on average, aren't all pool tables?

best part is sinking a ball and then using the pool cue as a shot gun to mimic blowing your enemies out of the water. classic.
author: Jade L.

description: The perfect go-to local pub for you and your group of friends that you'll just want to return to again and again. The bartenders are friendly and knowledgeable, and the atmosphere is chill and good for conversation. On Saturdays it gets busy after 10pm, so try to get there a bit earlier than that if you want to grab a table. It's also conveniently located on Clement, so plenty of late night places open close by as well.  No cover.
author: Michelle L.

description:
My favorite pub in my area!  It's my kind of bar - great food (LOVE the fish & chips and the Gaelic Chicken) and an acceptable beer selection.  One of the few places that makes a good Black Velvet, too.  They get mad props for once having Fox Barrel cider on tap!

I'm also just really impressed by the staff.  Most nights I'm there I only see one woman working the bar AND waitressing tables getting dinner.  They seem pretty short-handed, but I'm always pleasantly greeted and have a great night there.
author: Elise M.

description: Decent bar but all the pool tables were fucked up. Decent songs were being played so I guess we can say there was a decent crowd. Not sure if I'll be back.
author: Jack A.

description: Really like this bar because they have decent food and beer selection.  They also have an upstairs area with pool and darts and it's never too crowded to where you can't usually play.  I've come here for Trivia and to play darts and chat and have always found it a good spot to meet up with friends and get friendly service.
author: Nirea S.

description:
Just came back from the Trivia night!

SUPER friendly bartender! My boyfriend left his card there, and remembered an hour later, went back, and fortunately the bartender was still there and he got his card back.

Beer pitchers for $12.

Pool tables+darts upstairs. 

I need some sleep now.

Word of Advice= think of a clever team name and get a round of shots on the house for the whole team. Winner of trivia night gets $30. 
GET THERE EARLY to get a table. Or go for dinner so you definitely have a table. It gets PACKED around 9 o'clock.

Okay sleep time for me. That was real fun.
author: Erica L.

description:
This is a pretty fun bar to go to. The main street level room is nice, with plenty of old, antique, wooden furnishings. There is plenty of seating, TVs, and 49er fans. To get past the bar you must squeeze your way through the hoards of people.  Very helpful and friendly staff.

Make your way upstairs and you'll find a pool table that was missing a que ball, an apparently broken pinball machine, and an area with two dart boards. The positive aspect of the upstairs is their high-quality darts, a rare find in my opinion. The downside is the lighting--it's downright terrible. More light (or better quality) upstairs, please.
author: Noah W.

description:
I have four things to say about this place:

1) Boddingtons Pub Ale on tap
2) Gets crowded
3) Lots of good places to eat around here
4) Boddingtons Pub Ale on tap
author: Marlon T.

description:
Spur of moment stop after The Green Apple Bookstore. 
Black Velvet (Guinness & Wyder hard cider) awesome.
This is a pub, not a pick up joint. Very comfortable.
author: DeeAnn B.

description:
Nice neighborhood bar. It's wholesome fun. $3 dollar draft brew til 8pm. 

Tons of seating, just get there early. Good friendly type of atmosphere, not that the people there are friendly but you know. 

The bar doesn't have much of a personality imo. 

Feels like a bar on the Haight.
author: Earl G.

description:
My friends and I stopped by, wanting to give Trivia Night a go. We didn't realize it starts at 9PM and we arrived at 7:30. By then, the bar was pretty packed, with only a few seats and tables open. 

The waitresses here are very friendly and helpful. We asked about Trivia Night and one of them gave us a pretty detailed description about how it works. Because it was still Happy Hour, we decided to try all 3 different flavors of cider. I've never had cider before, but it's really just like sparkling cider with a hint of alcohol. Out of all three flavors (pear, apple, and raspberry), I prefered the pear. At only $3/glass during HH, that was a pretty good deal in my mind. 

Expect an extremely loud environment. I guess that's the bar-scene but I'm not quite used to it. I would definitely come back for some grub, more cider, and maybe even have a go at some trivia!
author: Stephanie L.

description: All their bar food items are great and the service is great! Meet one of the bartenders from Florida on a Wednesday night and ended up taking shots. Haha. Great location and great vibes!
author: Dianna C.

description:
Met up with a friend just before happy-hour finished up, and ordered 3-$3 pints. For two people, we had 5 drinks (2 at regular price), fish and chips, chicken burger, and the walnut salad. With tip was $57. Not bad. Waitress took a liking to me, cuz I smile and act normal. Hint hint.

Fish and chips were good, and the chicken burger was char broiled (which I liked but my friend didn't). Salad was good, but a little strong on the dressing. Almost couldn't taste the leafy greens. Fries are good, but I think they are frozen, but at least the cook knows how to fry a fry a fry a fry a fry. It's bar food, so it's comfort food, and a scale above other's I've had in the city.

One less star for strange yeasty smell that hovers in the place. I mean I'm guessing it's either from the Malt Vinegar, or spilt beer. It's a bar, after all, but I'm a clean freak. Leave me alone.

Thankfully the music wasn't loud, so I didn't have to raise my voice to have a conversation. Music choice wasn't bad either, some classic rock, newer rock. No hip-hop, which is a good choice for this bar and it's clientele.
author: S D.

description:
Pull up a stool, make yourself at home. The bartenders all have accents, the beer is cold, and  the food is greasy... as it should be.

If you're looking for a bar to meet a friend and have a beer or seven, this is a perfect spot. Bring your own friends though, this is not the kinda place you're gonna find a new BFF. It's not fancy, but it has everything you love and very little of the stuff you hate. A dark, old, friendly hide-out, with a juke box full of music you have to be 30+ to appreciate. A SF oasis, 96% free of appletinis, striped shirts, indoor sunglasses, prada hand bags and orange fist pumps.

Stay away on Trivia Tuesday's if you want to get a table, a beer or hear yourself think. There are 3 TV's at the bar if you don't feel like talking to anyone, as well as a couple pool tables and darts upstairs for your ADD pal that can't sit still for an hour. 

One last thing... If you have a sense of humor, please bring a sharpie. The unclever bathroom graffiti is the only disappointing thing about this place.
author: Kevin A.

description: Cosmo, too strong as a girly drink. Liked how there's many seatings, but the bar didn't really excite me in any way. Probably came on a bad night, shall try their Trivia Night some time.
author: Elaine Y.

description:
A couple of years ago, my roommate and her then-boyfriend came here to break up. He is now her EX-boyfriend and they no longer speak.

A couple of weeks ago, I came here with an ex from about a year ago to have a drink. We caught up, shared some laughs, and actually had a good time.

Which of the two is more ironic given the name of this bar, I'm not too sure. All I have to say is, it's a nice bar, Colma the Musical filmed a scene here, and life, in fact, is more circular than linear. The end.

Or is it?
author: Kate V.

description:
If you know me (and you probably don't), you know that I will always always ALWAYS prefers pubs over clubs. Always. They're just better. Period. 

That being said, my buddy took my here after eating at King of Thai. As soon as I set my foot in that doorway, I knew I would like it here a lot. A pint of Sierra Nevada for $3.50??? Why, yes, please, I would love one...or two....or six. Yup.

We spent a considerable amount of time here shooting pool upstairs. So that alone gives this place at least 4 stars. Add in the awesome bartender, great ambiance, and the beautiful woman who bumped into me by accident during my shot, we have ourselves a winner! In fact, I had such a good time, I totally forgot about the Warriors losing against the Mavericks!

...Awwww...writing that just made me remember...

Still, it's a good place to be. Guaranteed.
author: Daniel M.

description: Brought in some out-of-town friends to eat here.  Food was good and atmosphere was full of good energy.  Went upstairs to show them pool table  but to my surprise.....get ready.....THEY HAVE NEW DARTBOARDS!!!!!!  It's about time.....the old boards were disintegrating into powder.  The boardss are AWESOME!!!!!!  Looks really nice now...maybe next they can clean up the upstairs area a bit (and add more light????)  But overall a great place and two new boards!!!!
author: Jean Y.

description:
Quiet on an early Saturday afternoon.  

It was a cold day, and we looked up "fireplace" on Yelp.  Several nearby bars came up, and we wandered around the neighborhood trying to decide on a good one.  As we passed The Bitter End I reminded my Love that it was on the list, so we went in.  

The front of the bar was Brit style, and the back of the bar was American style.  Although the Big Game was on TV, there were hardly more than a dozen patrons.  The Genuine Irish Bartender was keeping up with the demand quite well, and was happy to fix a glass of white wine for my Lady and a hot toddy for me, for $11 + tip.  

Lo and behold, the table directly in front of the fireplace was open, and we enjoyed our drinks basking in the direct heat of the flames.  

The menu looked decent, and Stanford kicked Bears' butts like nobody's business today.  No patrons were injured in the ensuing mêlée.
author: David D.

description: Love this place. Upstairs/downstairs. I believe it's a English Pub ? But bartenders are all Irish. Super good service. Trivia night (which I don't attend), good atmosphere for Football games on TV, and within stones throw of 4 other bars. Food seems to be mediocre at best. But I don't think it's a destination for grub, just helps keep you there. 5 stars for sure though.
author: Ben S.

description:
Had dinner at Q then came by with friends to grab beers on a Friday night.  Really liked the vibe, lively and fun, good place to let loose.  We parked ourselves around the far pool table upstairs and had a great time.  

I'm pretty sure one of the bartenders was hammered.  But honestly, that was more entertaining than irritating.
author: Rich L.

description:
If you have the propensity to retain obscure facts, would do well on the game show "Are You Smarter than a 5th Grader," or are that person who has filled up their 160 GB iPod with songs and can name the song title and artist of most songs you hear, then you want be at The Bitter End on Tuesday nights at 9 pm for TRIVIA NIGHT! 

Three rounds of trivia which include random facts to test your breadth of knowledge, name that tune (artist and song title), and some random category with questions on a related topic. If you do decide to stop by for trivia night it's best to get here some time before 9 pm to get a table for you and your group. The incentive to get here early is the $2 draft beer specials from 8pm to 9pm. You can't beat that! First through third place winners of trivia night get some cash flow to disperse amongst their team, winners of the best team name get free shots, and they also have raffles throughout the night for a chance to win free t-shirts. 

This pub is awesome for some good group fun -- decent beer selection on tap, good buffalo wings (even though they are more sweet and tangy as opposed to spicy), and surprisingly good service.  I think my only complaint would be the limited music library on the jukebox.
author: Erich D.

description:
Hmm...I came here because a bunch of my friends came here before to play trivia and had lots of fun, so I thought I'd come check it out with them andsee what the appeal was.

So after an hour of agonizing nausea, I am so happy to get out of the car and arrive at this place, only to find myself around all this Chinese stuff. Oh confusion. Turns out we parked a few blocks down, no biggie. We have a friend already there who had grabbed us a table and we all ordered a bunch of food. My Cesar salad was alright, I noticed the chicken was pretty dry on the salad and for the chicken strips as well. But their ranch was good, mmm ranch. Their french fries are steak cut, nothing fantastic about them, but they did hit the spot when I was starving. 

I had a taste of my friends food, it wasn't very impressive to me, but it's pretty decent to get at a bar. The drinks seemed to be decently strong, $5 grabs you a pitcher of PBR and a shot of jager...good deal, good deal.

The trivia was so freakin' obscure. They do it in 4 rounds, the first is general trivia, second is music recognition, third is picture matching, and fourth is general trivia. The winners get some money and the team with the funniest name gets a free round of shots. After trivia, the crowd pretty much thinned out.

It was alright, a bit too dark for my squinty eyes, and too loud to have a coherent conversation with anyone inside the premises. The servers are decently attentive for how busy it seemed to be, and for a while, everyone was very focused on their trivia.

There's an upstairs for bathrooms, pool, darts, etc. and the downstairs area. It gets kind of squishy, so beware of pressing up against people if you're trying to reach the bar.

Oh yeah, also I hear their $2 beers went up this week to $2.50. Gasp! The outrage!
author: Grace Y.

description:
Sometimes rowdy, sometimes raucous, but always fun.
Booths and tables in front, bar in the back.

Trivia is fun on Tuesdays(?) and that really gets the place packed.

Haven't tried the food yet, didn't even know they served food until I saw the cook come out of the kitchen one time!
author: Ken B.

description:
Cozy, congenial to conversation and group gatherings, it's more of a beer than a liquor place (or certainly not a cocktail place), and if you're starving they've got an edible cheesesteak among other options from a pretty large menu for a bar.

It's relatively clean and the staff is relatively friendly. It is, however, shockingly busy seemingly without reason on weeknights past 10 sometimes. Very loud, but maybe that's what you're looking for.
author: Caroline C.

description:
I prefer a good pub over a crowded bar with authentic pub food and this place didn't disappoint overall. Went on Tues. night (trivia night) and though I am NOT a trivia buff, my friend and I wanted to watch the rest of the Sharks game and see our new favorite bartender, Pascal. 

After some obnoxiously loud frat/sorority kids mucking up the ambiance, we managed to have pepper steak, calamari, zucchini sticks, several drinks and who knows what else! Food was good (not excellent like in the previous times but still very delicious), drinks were strong and cold and of course, Pascal checked in on us without hovering! That's a damn good bartender. Most will guilt you into drinking more or ignore you to talk to some lousy pair of boobs. This guy knew quality boobs :)

In the end, I left with lemons from the bartender's lemon tree and reconnected with an old friend who was playing with his crew at trivia night. Love the attentive but not suffocating service and the menu is quite good too.
author: Liliana A.

description: This place is a staple for me and my friends. They have a jam packed Trivia night. Get there early if you want to sit during the festivities! The best of the best dive bars! The staff is amazing. This place also has an upstairs with pool tables and dart boards!
author: Ray K.

description:
Had a good time here playing pool with some friends here last night. Even though my pool playing leaves a lot to be desired, luckily my partner is a bit of a shark.

The place is nice, I lucked out on parking (though it seems like it could get tough at times). Jovial Crowd. Newcastle on tap. Mmmmmm. I look for that.

I just wish they had a sign on the bathroom that said "Ladies Room" or "Senoritas" or SOMETHING so I didn't have to go trying to open like every other closet door to find it (for some reason the Men's room is marked Men but there's nothing on the women's room).  Even if they didn't put "Ladies room" on it....  "Restroom" or "Bathroom" would have been fine. SOMETHIN... throw me a bone here, people.... Lord knows what I'm gonna find if I keep opening all these little side doors in a bar full of drunken college students!
author: Laura S.

description: Love this place! Great beer, good prices, & LOVE sitting by the fireplace!
author: Amanda B.

description: This is one of my favorite neighborhood bars  in the Richmond. Great people behind the bar - awesome trivia on Tuesdays - and an awesome atmosphere. Also the drinks are cheap!!!
author: Nick T.

description:
Let me be clear- I love this place.  The dark woods, lots of televisions, and the extremely friendly wait staff with thick Irish accents, all within walking distance of my apartment mean this: the Bitter End is a staple of our weekends.  

The bar is tall and narrow, with an upstairs balcony, where there is pool and darts.  

Even when we've come just to watch a Sharks game, the food is decent and the service is fine.

The absolute best part about the Bitter End, is that it is not trying to be anything that it is not.  It IS a casual bar.

My one complaint is that they need to figure out a better way to play music- as up front is way too loud, especially when there aren't a lot of people there.

Weekends, it gets crowded, and if you're up for trivia- expect to get there early.
author: Richard Y.

description: This used to be a comfortable and friendly neighborhood bar. Unfortunately the last time I went, the bartender Martina would not serve me possibly because I'm a woman of color or she thought I was underage but didn't ask to see my ID. Whatever it was, I waited almost 35 minutes at the bar to get a drink. After being confronted, she told my friends and I to leave. The Bitter End is definitely going to lose most of their business to the friendlier new bars in the neighborhood like The Richmond Republic.
author: Jennifer H.

description: This Irish pub in the Richmond has good beers on tap, friendly service, ample space and pool tables upstairs (though they're pretty old and not in fantastic shape). $6 Irish coffee is great for a chilly day. Definitely recommend, but note that this bar is **CASH ONLY** (I think they do have an ATM machine in the bar, though).
author: Kate B.

description:
Great dive.  I'm talking old wood, juke box, and 2 people working out front that are friendly as hell.  4 flat screens to watch games.  And great pub food!!!  GREAT.  Repeatable items are the sampler and the garlic fries!

The neighborhood has a handful of dive bars and I always start & end with Bitter.  

Ladies- the parameter wall trim has coat/purse hangers.  You know you have to love that!
author: Deanna A.

description: I came in here yesterday with a friend and was hoping for a really good experience based on the reviews. We walked in and there were a decent amount of people at the bar but not many for dinner (it was around 6:30pm). There was only one bartender with about 20 customers. When I got my drinks we sat down at one of the tables looking to order food. After 5 minutes, we realized they didnt have any servers so I went to the bar and asked for menus. After figuring out what we wanted, I had to go back to the bartender to place the orders. The menu looked pretty good; i got the chicken piccata and my friend the appitizer sampler. The food was alright, but nothing amazing. I could have easily given this place a 3 star review if they had another person helping. To have only one person for that busy of a time just didnt make sense to me..
author: Tyler L.

description:
I happened upon this pub on my way to a comedy show at the Rockit Room (across the street). I had some time to kill and wanted to catch the first part of the Giants/ Reds game. The Bitter End is a really great place to hang out and you can tell this is place is welcoming of sports fans. There is sports memorabilia decorating the area around the bar but it's not overdone or gaudy. Most of the interior is wood and it gives it a very traditional feel. The servers and bartender all had accents which added to the traditional pub feel. 

During the happy hour I had a pint of a black velvet/ snake bite ($3). There was more cider than beer- more than I'm used to, but it was still good. Assuming the accents are real and these people are from alcohol-drinking countries in Europe, perhaps having more cider in the drink is the way it's supposed to be served. 

I'm not sure where the music was coming from but they were playing Bob Dylan and Beatles. I thought someone had swiped my iPod for a sec. 

I read some other reviews and I'm thinking I'll go back to check out the Trivia Tuesday event. I know tons of useless information and perhaps this is finally a place to put those random facts to good use.
author: Daisy S.

description:
DRINKS:
1.) Jester Beer = Avoid. lol. Tastes like pear cider beer or something. 

*Sad beer selection, but there was Heff, Stella, & Sierra at least. O wells, I still take it for a local bar to hang out and play pool and fling darts for almost free.



SERVICE:
$20 limit on credit card? Lame. 



ATMOSPHERE:
On a Monday night, but my personal Friday night. This place is so chil. Dart boards, pool tables. Swweeeeeet. Two floors, so it looks kinda cool. Like a saloon almost. Whole place looks like it's made out of dark old wood. Bathroom conveniently upstairs next to the darts. Anyway my sole tells me she goes here for the Trivia night. She loves it. We will be back. For sure.
author: Angela L.

description:
I came here for trivia night. 

I'd say if you're drunk and the people around you aren't, you're not going to get away with using an iPhone or blackberry.

If you're sober and the people around you are drunk, you're going to get away with using an iPhone or blackberry.

Not that I condone the use of one or anything ... in the bathroom especially. 

p.s If they show you a baby photo of a girl/boy that looks like Eminem, it's Lindsay Lohan.
author: Allen L.

description: Love this place. Perfect place to wait for a table down the street at Burma Superstar. ;)
author: Mindy M.

description:
It's hard for an Irish pub to go wrong.  Put up some dark wood paneling, offer Guinness, and provide fish & chips or bangers and mash.  The Bitter End - named either after the end of a sheet on a sailboat, or a long night of drinking, take your pick - is a prime specimen of Irish pubbery.

Step through the rickety front door and observe: dark wood paneling.  To your left are sizable tables appropriate for comfortably seating 6.  On the right is a cozy set up next to a fireplace and flat screen.  Continue to the back, where you will find the bar - whence the barman purveys Guinness, fish & chips, etcetera - and some booth seating.  They pour a good Guinness.  Also, I have witnessed all manner of tasty looking edibles be served to fellow patrons: salads, sandwiches, burgers, fries, and of course, bangers & mash.

Come here when it's quiet to do some reading over a pint, or when it's loud to watch a game and be rowdy.  Just make sure you come!
author: Dmytro A.

description: So goofy with sloppy ass girls and dudes. I don't even know what else to say, it pretty much sums it up.
author: Lori C.

description:
Easily my absolute favorite bar in the city, The Bitter End is the shining example of what a neighborhood bar should be. Tuesday night trivia is a local institution, just come with enough people to either win, or wallow in your ineptitude with friends. Whats more important, by the time the event is over, most teams are too drunk to really care. A music round, a singalong and a limerick are all parts of the fun, and the 2.50 pint specials are always fun.

 Smarter teams usually show up well before the 9pm starting time to ensure seating, with premium seats near the fireplace, along the bar or on the balcony by the darts for larger teams. Enjoyable chow is easily had at reasonable (read: san francisco) prices and the kitchen is open till 10. 

 Finally, the bar staff is friendly, quick and always willing to make another neighborhood friend. Make sure you lift a pint with one of them whenever you get a chance!
author: Jason C.

description: One of my favorite places to go to when I'm in the Inner Richmond! They have a good selection of beer, their mixed drinks are not watered down and the bartenders are always fun to talk to when they aren't too busy. I always try to bring friends that are visiting San Francisco. If you want to have a good time with friends and get some good cheap drinks in an up and coming neighborhood this is the place to go to!
author: Edgar R.

description: Horrible service gets this review two stars, but their food is frozen, expensive scotch watered down, and one of their pool tables is broken.
author: Jacob T.

description:
In an attempt to continue my search for fun, late night hangout spots, a WHOLE BUNCH of my co-workers and I came here for a big birthday bash.  Even though I'm considered somewhat of a lightweight, I do enjoy bars that exude an energy that most others don't.

There was an entire 2nd level area with dart boards, a game which some people take far too seriously, I must say, pool tables, bar stools, and other various seating setups that made for a more private group gathering away from the downstairs crowds.

I ordered their Bacon Avocado Cheeseburger with fries... a delight when you're starving and about to drink.  Their New Castle... I would classify as tastier than your average New Castle on tap at most other bars that even serve it on tap.  

Great atmosphere, bartenders are friendly as hell, and the environment provides a grand 'ol time.
author: Johnson N.

description:
Cool place.  Just dark enough to be cozy, but plenty of light to see where you're going.
Upstairs and downstairs areas are open to all.  
Some videogames.
A few pool tables.
Some tableside servers.
Cool bartenders.
Laid-back bouncer.
Have Tuesday trivia nights!
Have some food. 
Almost always room to sit, or at least stand comfortably, without being a sardine in a can.
author: Fannie S.

description: The Bitter End is a place that affords one the leisure of enjoying their beer at a reasonable price, and they also have pretty decent food items if you're a not-so-connoisseur of bar foods (a burger to fill the belly). It's got darts, a pool table up top and trivia nights on Tuesdays. All in all, I'm a fan.
author: Brianna S.

description:
TUESDAY NIGHT TRIVIA!? Don't mind if I do! The guy, Oliver, that hosts it is way legit. Pretty funny, too. He always has these sassy little quips to accompany the less-than-attractive celebrity faces on the picture round.
Oliver hands out tickets that, If you're lucky, turn into shirts with names of alcohol on them.
Shots for the best (most socially insensitive) team name.
$30 CASH for 1st place, $20 2nd, $10 3rd. None of this bar tab bullshit that other places give.
Advice: get there early & try to score a seat under a speaker. The music round is sometimes hard to hear because people have trouble understanding the meaning of "shut the hell up".
If you're looking for a good way to spend your Tuesday nights while eating, drinking and showing off your brain: go to The Bitter End. Starts at 9, drink specials all night!
author: Meghan B.

description:
Came to San Francisco only knowing one person. I decided to check out this local watering whole down the street from my apartment. I ended coming here two nights in a row. 

The first night, I met some very nice people and ended shooting pool with them. In was a slow night, but the waitress was super sweet. 

The second night, it happened to be Trivia Night. I teamed with with two people I met earlier on and we tried our hand in it. The questions can be tough, but you'll have fun doing it.

Although its major selling point is the awesome crowd it attracts, its not a bad place to eat either.  Great pub food. Great selection of beer. And I know this is nothing new to San Francisco locals, but $4 for a Corona is just insane for an LA native. 

All in all, I love this place. Not a bad way to introduce myself to Inner Richmond, as well as San Francisco.
author: Adam F.

description:
I'm rating this based primarily on my experiences @ TBE with large groups of friends... so we made our evenings here fun regardless of what was happening elsewhere in the bar, if you catch my drift.

The Bitter End. A cozy, dependable neighborhood dive bar. Apparently pretty popular with other USF students in the neighborhood, judging by the reviews. It was relegated to "fallback option" (which = our go-to bar) within my first several weeks of living in the Inner Richmond, though it did get rather old rather quickly.

It's usually super packed when I walk by, and Tuesday trivia nights can be a hoot (and even MORE crowded, if possible)! As dives go, this is a good one, and you'll find a fun little community here.
author: Sam S.

description:
Came here one night with friends and it was pretty good. The bartenders are extremely friendly with awesome Irish accents. The beer is nice and cold, and the ambience of the place is great. There are two levels, with the bar being on the first, and two pool tables on the second. It's nice to go with friends for a quick drink at night, and to play some pool.

Only thing I'd have to complain about is the fact that the pool tables are really close to the walls. You'll have to struggle a little to hit without scratching the game, because you'll literally have to tilt your stick at a 45-degree angle to avoid the wall.
author: Jason T.

description:
Laid-back.  No weird smells.  An upstairs, as well as a pool table.  Numerous brews on tap. Tables galore.  Food's actually pretty tasty, and the restrooms are very decent.

The Bitter End is the place to bring your parents- no error there.  Yet, it's also the place to come to after a long day putting in those hours downtown.
